TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE ( ORG ) . She is a regular warrant officer in ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant is a regular member of the armed forces and has been married to CARDINAL of her colleagues since CARDINAL DATE . Since joining the army she has received an “ unmarried person ’s ” service allowance which is designed to compensate for the unique requirements that service life imposes on military personnel .

After she married she requested her service allowance to be re - calculated at the higher “ head of the family ” rate paid to her husband . She relied on the LOC judgment of CARDINAL DATE in which the ORG d’Etat had declared obsolete the reference to the notion of head of the family in the light of the provisions of LAW of DATE . This judgment had had the effect of making servicewomen married to servicemen eligible for the “ head of the family ” service allowance instead of the “ unmarried person ’s ” service allowance for the same family situation .
Relying on that case - law authority , the applicant asked the military authorities to bring her service allowance into line with the higher allowance paid to her husband . Her request was refused .
On DATE she appealed to the Chief of ORG of ORG .

Basing his decision on the decree of CARDINAL DATE governing service allowances , the Chief of ORG dismissed her appeal on DATE on the ground that , where a serviceman and servicewoman were married to each other , family expenses could not be taken into account twice and the “ head of the family ” allowance paid to both spouses .

On DATE the applicant lodged an application with ORG for judicial review of ORG decision . In her submission , no provision of the DATE decree supported the ministry ’s refusal to grant her a “ head of the family ” allowance and the ministry ’s interpretation of the decree had been discriminatory .
On DATE the court set aside the ministry ’s decision on the following grounds :

“ Firstly , the provisions of LAW of DATE have rendered otiose the notion of head of the family referred to in the aforementioned decree of CARDINAL DATE governing service allowances and secondly , ORG has no legislative or regulatory power to treat PERSON as an ‘ unmarried person’ for the purposes of the aforementioned provisions in refusing her the allowance requested . It follows , without there being any need to examine the ground submitted under LAW of DATE , that PERSON is justified in requesting judicial review of the aforementioned decision of CARDINAL DATE refusing her a ‘ head of the ORG service allowance from DATE . ”
On DATE ORG passed LAW for DATE , which came into force on the date of its publication in ORG ) on DATE . Section CARDINAL-II of that LAW provides :

“ Subject to final court decisions , individual service allowances that are challenged on the basis of the effects of LAW of DATE ( Law no . CARDINAL ) on the provisions of Decree no . DATE of CARDINAL DATE governing service allowances are hereby validated . ”
On DATE the Minister of Defence appealed against ORG judgment relying on , inter alia , section CARDINAL-II of DATE .
In an order of DATE the President of ORG upheld the judgment of ORG .

The Minister of Defence appealed to the PERSON d’Etat , which , in a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , set aside the judgment of ORG . It held that the ground of appeal based on the submission that the notion of the “ head of the family ” referred to in the decree of CARDINAL DATE had become obsolete was no longer valid following the enactment of the legalising LAW DATE . The ORG d’Etat noted , among other things , that

“ The effect [ of ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the decree of CARDINAL DATE ] is that any married member of the armed forces , regardless of sex , may receive the “ head of the family ” service allowance but , where both spouses are members of the armed forces , the higher family allowances are non - cumulative and are paid to the head of the household alone . PERSON and her husband ’s entitlement to a service allowance was determined on that basis . It is not disputed that the applicant ’s husband has already received the “ head of the family ” allowance . The Minister of Defence ’s subsequent dismissal of the applicant ’s claim for the head of the family allowance on the ground that her husband had already received it does not in itself infringe the principle that men and women should receive equal pay for equal work ... ”
CARDINAL . Civil Code

Under LAW ( LAW of DATE ( Law no . CARDINAL ) ) “ spouses are jointly responsible for the family ’s moral and material well - being . They are responsible for their children ’s upbringing and for preparing their future ” .
Legislative and regulatory provisions governing service allowances

“ Officers and rank - and - file personnel in receipt of a DATE salary shall be paid an expenses allowance known as a ‘ service ORG to compensate for the various specifically military obligations and in particular frequent changes in postings . ”
“ The service allowance shall vary according to the recipient ’s rank and their family and housing situation . ”
“ The DATE rates of the service allowance shall be determined by joint order of the Minister of Defence , the Minister for ORG and Finance and the Minister of State for ORG .
“ The following shall be regarded as the head of the family:-
married members of the armed forces ;
other military personnel having CARDINAL dependent child or living with their widowed mother , on condition that she habitually lives under their roof and is not liable for income tax .
The definition of ‘ dependent child’ shall be that used in the tax legislation . ”

“ Military personnel in receipt of the head of the family service allowance who receive a change of posting for the requirements of the ORG entailing a relocation within the meaning of the above - mentioned decree of CARDINAL DATE shall be paid a flat - rate salary supplement ... ”

“ Military personnel in receipt of the head of the family service allowance shall also be paid an extra flat - rate supplement on the occasion of each posting imposed for Service reasons and entailing a relocation within the meaning of the aforementioned decree of DATE . This supplement shall be payable from the seventh posting for officers , and from the fourth posting for the rank and file , calculated DATE in respect of non - commissioned officers and senior corporals DATE from the date on which they qualify for a DATE salary and DATE in respect of corporals and soldiers – from the date on which they qualify for a special incremental salary ... ”

“ Subject to final court decisions , individual service allowances that are challenged on the basis of the effects of LAW of DATE ( Law no . CARDINAL ) on the provisions of Decree no . DATE of CARDINAL DATE governing service allowances are hereby validated . ”
In the GPE decision of CARDINAL DATE the ORG d’Etat ruled as follows :

“ In refusing PERSON , née GPE , who is a ORG captain , a flat - rate supplement to the service allowance ... , the Minister of Defence had regard solely to the fact that she was receiving an ‘ unmarried person’s’ allowance ... and to the fact that Lieutenant PERSON , her husband , receives the ‘ head of the family’ service allowance .

Firstly , the provisions of LAW of DATE have rendered otiose the notion of head of the family expressly referred to in the aforementioned decree of CARDINAL DATE governing family expenses allowances and , secondly , ORG does not have any legislative or regulatory power to treat PERSON , née GPE , as an ‘ unmarried person’ in refusing to grant her the allowance requested . It follows that PERSON , née GPE , is justified in maintaining that , in the decisions complained of , ORG wrongly refused to award her the flat - rate supplement to the service allowance . ”
In the Minister of Defence v. ORG judgment of DATE , the ORG d’Etat held :

“ Bonuses paid to military personnel for skills and meritorious service are claims that must be regarded as possessions within the meaning of LAW No . CARDINAL to LAW . The aforementioned provisions of section CARDINAL of the DATE Act were enacted after the ORG d’Etat , sitting in its judicial capacity , had decided on DATE that military personnel serving abroad continued to enjoy all the permanent fringe benefits and after the decree of CARDINAL DATE had amended the decree of CARDINAL DATE to prevent non - commissioned officers serving abroad from receiving the allowances . These provisions , which came into force after Mr ORG had brought his dispute with the ORG before ORG , had the effect of depriving him retroactively of his entitlement to the allowances . Neither the aim of preventing military personnel serving abroad from maintaining the benefits in question during the transitional period preceding publication of the decree of DATE , nor the aim of avoiding any discrimination arising between civil servants and members of the armed forces or between servicemen and women who have taken legal proceedings and those who have not , nor the concern to avoid the financial consequences of the aforementioned decision of the ORG d’Etat qualify as grounds of public interest of a kind to justify the interference with PERSON ORG ’s possessions brought about by the retroactive deprivation of the bonus for skills and meritorious service to which he was legally entitled during his postings abroad . Accordingly , we reject as ill - founded the Minister of Defence ’s submission that ORG erred in law in ruling that the provisions of section CARDINAL were incompatible with those of LAW No . CARDINAL to ORG . ... ”
